awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to achieve an in-depth understanding of the physics of a new class of magnetic material: ferri-magnets, and to create a new kind of memory device to resolve the bottleneck in speed and energy beyond today's technologies. The success of the proposed research will surely set an important milestone for next-generation information and communications technology. The research is closely aligned with industrial needs to provide new directions, which may thus fuel another wave of innovation for socio-economic growth. The impact is transformative because it aims at the discovery of novel functional nanomaterials as well as the new physics for high density, high speed, and ultra-high efficient devices. The forefront research will also have a vast educational impact since the research trains students with various education levels,  from high school to undergraduate/graduate school (including women and minorities) as well as school teachers in this inter- and multi-disciplinary and emerging fields of physical science, engineering, and computer science, through PI's participation of the outreach programs at UCLA. The training in these emerging disciplines will provide a diverse human capital, versed in scientific methods and experienced in the applications. The educational impact is further amplified by the existing outreach programs established in the UCLA NSF Engineering Research Center.  

Ultra-fast and energy-efficient memory devices are critical to resolving the limit of speed and energy dissipation for today's computing challenges in the era of big data and artificial intelligence.  The proposed research is aimed at realizing a radically different class of memory devices based on insulating ferrimagnetic materials, which can operate at terahertz speed due to the enormous internal exchange field. In particular, these materials usually have low damping, enabling high energy efficiency. The major tasks are to understand and control the dynamics of nearly compensated ferri-magnets and to build ferri-magnetic prototype memories.  To accomplish the objective, the proposed research will investigate a series of new insulating ferri-magnets from three perspectives: (1) understanding the fundamental switching mechanism and the interfacial exchange coupling between a compensated ferrimagnet and a large spin-orbit-coupling layer through electrical characterizations, pump-probe, x-ray, and neutron techniques; (2) enabling electrical manipulation of the compensated ferrimagnetic order to be demonstrated by anomalous Hall and magnetoresistance effects; (3) realizing their ultrafast dynamics using electronic ultrashort pulses and optical pump-probing in the picosecond regime. Fundamentally, the research will enable the understanding of the interface coupling and the ferri-magnetic dynamics, resulting in new switching mechanisms.  It may provide a new framework for employing spintronics in quantum technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The spintronics devices that utilizes the electron?s spin degree of freedom as information storage media. The non-volatility and high endurance of magnetic materials are unique among all memory available to date for this new application. The manipulation of the spin states via electric field or current provides the capability of in-memory computing, beyond the conventional von Neumann computational paradigm, which makes spintronic devices have lower power consumption. Compared to the ferromagnetic materials that have been widely researched in spintronics, ferrimagnet/antiferromagnets offer fundamental advantages in terms of high frequency dynamics up to terahertz. Together with high energy efficient topological insulator for driving current induced spin-orbit torque, ultra-fast and energy-efficient memory devices has the potential to revolutionize data processing by enabling faster read and write operations while reducing energy consumption.

This project employed a multidisciplinary approach, combining experimental and theoretical techniques. Growth techniques, such as molecular beam epitaxy and sputtering, were employed to synthesize thin films of the magnetic materials and topological insulators. The synthesized samples were characterized using state-of-the-art measurement techniques, including magnetometry, X-ray
diffraction, Kerr microscope, and cross-sectional scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM). Micron sized devices were fabricated for ultrafast electrical and optical measurements.

For ferrimagnet, CoFeGd was chosen due to its high tunability of two sublattice magnetization for composition engineering. Plasmonic photoconductive switch was employed to generate THz electrical pulses by femtosecond (150?200 fs) laser pulses, which was used to provide ultrafast spin- orbit torque (SOT) switching of CoFeGd magnetization (Fig. 1(a)). To make the SOT- magnetic random-access memory (MRAM) more practical, field free SOT switching is required. Through precise control over thickness and composition of CoFe and Gd, field free SOT switching was achieved with induced the chiral symmetry broken (Fig. 1(b)). Compared to the other field free SOT switching methods, the chiral symmetry breaking by the antisymmetric Dzyaloshinskii−Moriya
interaction (DMI) is topologically protected; therefore, it is robust against defects and boundaries in nanodevices. For antiferromagnet (AFM), a new current-induced N?el order switching mechanism was explored in FeRh with record-low current density on the order 10 6 A cm −2 facilitated by the unique AFM-ferromagnetic (FM) phase transition. By introducing a transient FM state via current-induced Joule heating, the spin-orbit torque can switch the AFM order parameter by 90? with a reduced writing current density similar to ordinary FM materials (Fig. 1(c)).

Giant spin-orbit torque (SOT) from topological insulators (TIs) provides an energy efficient writing method for magnetic memory writing method for magnetic memory, which, however, is still premature for practical applications due to the challenge of the integration with magnetic tunnel
junctions (MTJs). In this project, spin-to-charge conversion efficiency and thermal tolerance in topological insulators can be further enhanced by interface engineering. The SOT-MRAM cell is demonstrated in a TI-MTJ device with over 100% tunneling magnetoresistance (TMR) ratio, where
the energy consumption is significantly reduced due to the ultralow switching current density of 10 5 A cm −2 (Fig.1(d)).

The project findings were disseminated through peer-reviewed publications in leading scientific journals, ensuring widespread access to the research outcomes. The team actively participated in national and international conferences, presenting their results to the scientific community. Collaboration and knowledge exchange were fostered through workshops, seminars, and interactions with industry partners. These dissemination efforts facilitated the exchange of ideas and spurred further research in the field.

In summary, the project's findings hold great potential for revolutionizing data processing by enabling ultra-fast, energy-efficient, and non-volatile spintronics memory devices.
